awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: A home-compostable replacement to petroleum-based flexible packaging derived from seaweed
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a new type of melt-processable pellet made utilizing phycocolloids derived from different seaweed materials. Today, the commercial plastic packaging industry is reliant on the polymerization of petroleum derivatives, which are then compounded or melt-processed before being converted into finished goods. Mounting consumer backlash against plastic waste, domestic and international regulations, and an increased focus on curtailing dependence on petroleum are driving the demand for compostable packaging solutions that can service the biodegradable packaging market which is set to grow to $812 billion by 2030. By using seaweed as an alternative feedstock, the team's goal is to eliminate the need for more environmentally intensive inputs including petroleum as well as other terrestrial crops. Furthermore, this material technology is being designed for compatibility with existing plastic manufacturing infrastructure – thereby streamlining a path to scale and cost competitiveness. The anticipated outcome of this project is the development of the first commercially viable polymeric material predominantly derived from seaweed, that is melt-processed and compostable. This breakthrough will unlock a renewable plastic replacement that meets essential requirements for cost, scalability, and environmental impact. 

The intellectual merit of this project focuses on the development of a viable pathway for creating melt-processable pellets from seaweed. The goal is to enable the conversion of these pellets using conventional machinery to produce flexible film packaging. The main technical challenge to overcome in achieving successful commercialization is that seaweed materials do not melt at suitable processing temperatures, as do traditional polymers. Consequently, the resulting material does not possess the necessary mechanical properties required for flexible packaging. To address this challenge, the team will explore the tempering of seaweed chemistry and associated materials with selected commercial compostable polymers. This approach aims to achieve comparable strain at break, tensile strength, and stiffness to conventional thin film packaging while ensuring home compostability.  While previous research and applications have explored the use of seaweed for less economically viable film technologies, the unique contribution of this effort lies in combining varying seaweed chemistries and implementing them as a melt-processable seaweed material.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through our explorations under the NSF SBIR Phase I grant, Sway successfully developed the first commercially viable polymeric material predominantly derived from seaweed, that is both melt-processable and compostable.

Specifically, Sway developed substantial formulation advancements to our 100% biobased, melt-processable resin technology (TPSea™). TPSea™ serves as the foundation to Sway’s product portfolio, including TPSea Flex™: a home compostable flexible film that can replace conventional plastics across ubiquitous applications like polybags, polymailers, and retail bags.

A key technical challenge for developing seaweed-based biomaterials is overcoming the inherent thermal sensitivity of seaweed substrates, which causes them to decompose rather than melt under traditional plastic manufacturing conditions. By experimenting with semirefined seaweed inputs, tailored additives, and home-compostable polyesters under the NSF SBIR Phase I grant, Sway unlocked enhanced processability and mechanical performance.

The primary outcome of this project was Sway’s successful formulation and production of TPSea Flex™ prototypes with over 50% seaweed content and 90% renewable content. These formulations achieved compatibility with existing plastic manufacturing infrastructure, which enables traditional plastic manufacturers to work with our material at scale, without new equipment or major retooling. Leading prototypes were scaled using twin-screw extrusion to produce seaweed bioplastic pellets, which, when tested in lab-scale blown film production, exceeded expectations, thereby validating that Sway’smaterials can integrate seamlessly with industry-standard manufacturing processes and deliver high-quality outcomes. Notable breakthroughs included significant improvements in tensile strength, elongation at break, and tensile modulus – critical qualities for durable, flexible packaging, as underscored through SBIR Bootcamp user research.

The project outcomes of Phase I validate the production methods, scalability, and performance qualities of TPSea Flex™, demonstrating how our product can meet industry demands while aligning with Sway’s values of regeneration, circularity, and biobased innovation. By leveraging the unique properties of seaweed, this project has helped our company prove that scaling seaweed-based, home compostable packaging isn’t just an aspiration – it’s within reach.

Sway’s accomplishments through the NSF SBIR Phase I initiative underscore our leadership in biomaterial innovation and our commitment to transforming the packaging industry for the better. Together, we are creating materials that replenish the planet rather than extending it’s depletion.

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2025
Modified by: Mitra S Ganewatta
